    • un croissant (a croissant)
    • une pizza (a pizza)
    • une orange (an orange)

Grammar Focus

1. The Verb Être (To Be)

  • Conjugations introduced: je suis (I am), tu es (you are, singular informal), il est (he/it is), elle est (she is).
  • Used for introductions and descriptions (e.g., Je suis un garçon).

Pro-tip: Beginners often confuse tu es and je suis. Remember that suis starts with 's' like 'self' (I) and es ends with 's' like 'you' (tu).

summary:
Key A1 Vocabulary: Greetings, Farewells, and Basic Responses

  • Greetings and Inquiries:
    • Bonjour (Hello)
    • Bonjour, commen ça va? (Hello, how are you doing?/Hello, how are you?)
    • Tu mange un croissant? (Do you eat a croissant?)
  • Responses to Inquiries:
    • Ça va très bien, et toi? (It's going very well, and you?)
    • Ça va. (It's okay.)
    • Ça va bien, merci. Et toi? (Everything is fine, thank you. And you?)
    • Bien, merci. (Okay, well, thank you./Fine, thank you.)
    • Merci beaucoup. (Thank you very much.)
    • Non, je mange une pizza. (No, I'm eating a pizza.)
  • Farewells:
    • Au revoir (Goodbye)
    • Au revoir, bonne journée. (Goodbye, have a nice day.)
    • Bonne journée! (Have a nice day!)
    • Bon, à bientôt, alors? (Well, see you soon, then?)
    • Oui, à bientôt. (Yes, see you soon.)
    • Bon, à demain, alors? (All righty, then. / Well, see you tomorrow, then?)
    • Oui, à demain. (Yes, see you tomorrow.)

A1 Grammar Highlights

1. Informal Address: Using "Tu"

  • The phrases use the informal pronoun tu (you) and its corresponding verb forms, like in et toi? and Tu mange un croissant?.
  • The informal tu is used when speaking to friends, family, children, or people your own age.

Pro-tip: A common beginner mistake is confusing tu (informal) with vous (formal/plural). When in doubt with adults or people you don't know well

Vocabulaire Clé (Key Vocabulary)

  • Salutations & Basic Phrases:
    • Bonjour (Hello)
    • Excuse-moi (Excuse me)
    • Comment tu t'appelles? (What is your name?)

  • Nationalités & Identity:
    • français/française (French)
    • américain/américaine (American)
    • mexicain/mexicaine (Mexican)
    • espagnol/espagnole (Spanish)
    • Qui est...? (Who is...?)
  • Food & Preferences:
    • les croissants (croissants)
    • les éclairs (éclairs)
    • les gâteaux (cakes)
    • les fruits (fruit)

Grammaire et Verbes (Grammar and Verbs)

1. Le Verbe ÊTRE (To Be) & Nationalities

  • The verb être (to be) is used to express nationality and identity:
    • Je suis... (I am...)
    • Tu es...? (You are...?)
    • Il est... (He is...)
    • Elle est... (She is...)
  • Nationalities must agree in gender (masculine/feminine) with the person:
    • Masculine: français, américain, espagnol
    • Feminine: française, américaine, espagnole (often adding -e)

    • Pro-tip: Remember that the feminine forms (like américaine and française) are pronounced differently than the masculine forms. Pay attention to the extra 'e' which changes the final sound.
